SSG_Tools.Cameras
Class Camera

java.lang.Object
  SSG_Tools.Cameras.Camera
Direct Known Subclasses:
OrthographicCamera, PerspectiveCamera
public abstract class Camera
extends java.lang.Object

This class is the abstract base class for classes that use information about an observers position, view direction, near and far clipping planes to set the projection matrix and initial model view matrix to determine a view of the virtual world. A camera object is associated with a JoglPanel that displays a scene graph. The camera object determines how the scene is viewed, by allowing control of the position of the the observer (center of projection), the point in space where the observer is looking (view reference point), the up direction for the obseverd (view up vector), the view angle, and near and far clipping planes. In addition to basic methods for controlling the view, this class also defines a number of convenience methods for changing the view in "world coordinates", or the "observers UVN coordinates", getting the "line of sight" corresponding to a particular pixel, etc. The camera associated with a particular JoglPanel can be either a PerspectiveCamera, or an OrthographicCamera. A PerspectiveCamera is be used by default.

Method Detail

set

public void set(Camera camera)
Set values for the center of projection, view reference point, view up vector, new_plane, far_plane and view angle from the specified camera.

Parameters:
camera - The camera whose values are to be copied into this camera.

SetView

public void SetView(Vector3D cop,
                    Vector3D vrp,
                    Vector3D vuv)
Set values for the center of projection, view reference point and view up vector.

Parameters:
cop - Vector3D containing the x,y,z, coordinates of the center of projection
vrp - Vector3D containing the x,y,z, coordinates of the view reference point
vuv - Vector3D containing the x,y,z, coordinates of the view up vector

setCOP

public void setCOP(Vector3D cop)
Set a new value for the center of projection. The new COP must not be at the VRP, or so that (COP-VRP) is colinear with VUV. If the new COP is invalid, an error message will be printed and the method call is ignored.

Parameters:
cop - Vector3D containing the x,y,z, coordinates of the center of projection

getCOP

public Vector3D getCOP()
Get a copy of the current center of projection.

Returns:
A copy of the Vector3D containing the x,y,z, coordinates of the center of projection

setVRP

public void setVRP(Vector3D vrp)
Set a new value for the view reference point. The new VRP must not be at the COP, or so that (COP-VRP) is colinear with VUV. If the new VRP is invalid, an error message will be printed and the method call is ignored.

Parameters:
vrp - Vector3D containing the x,y,z, coordinates of the view reference point

getVRP

public Vector3D getVRP()
Get a copy of the current view reference point.

Returns:
A copy of the Vector3D containing the x,y,z, coordinates of the view reference point

setVUV

public void setVUV(Vector3D vuv)
Set a new value for the view up vector. The new VUV must not be colinear with (COP-VRP). If the new VUV is invalid, an error message will be printed and the method call is ignored.

Parameters:
vuv - Vector3D containing the x,y,z, coordinates of the view up vector

getVUV

public Vector3D getVUV()
Get a copy of the current view up vector.

Returns:
A copy of the Vector3D containing the x,y,z, coordinates of the view up vector

RotateAroundVRP

public void RotateAroundVRP(float angle,
                            Vector3D axis)
Set a new value for the COP and VUV by rotating the virtual camera through the specified angle, about the specified axis through the VRP. (NOTE: The scene will appear to rotate in the opposite direction.)

Parameters:
angle - The rotation angle in degrees.

RotateAroundCOP

public void RotateAroundCOP(float angle,
                            Vector3D axis)
Set a new value for the VRP and VUV by rotating the virtual camera through the specified angle, about the specified axis through the COP. (NOTE: The scene will appear to rotate in the opposite direction.)

Parameters:
angle - The rotation angle in degrees.

WorldCoordMove

public void WorldCoordMove(Vector3D move_vec)
Set new values for BOTH the VRP and COP by adding the specified world coordinate vector to them. (NOTE: The scene will appear to move in the opposite direction.)

Parameters:
move_vec - The world coordinate vector through which the VRP and COP are moved.

UVN_CoordMove

public void UVN_CoordMove(Vector3D move_vec)
Set new values for BOTH the VRP and COP by adding the specified vector, in the camera's local UVN coordnate system. If the "n" component of the move vector is zero, this will give a "PAN" motion. If the "u" and "v" coordinates are zero, this will give a dolly in motion if the "n" coordinate is positive and dolly out if the "n" coordinate is negative. (NOTE: The scene will appear to move in the opposite direction.)

Parameters:
move_vec - The UVN coordinate vector through which the VRP and COP are moved.

getU

public Vector3D getU()
Calculate the local "u" vector for the camera, pointing to the right from the camera's point of view, perpendicular to the line-of-sight.

Returns:
unit vector pointing to the right from the camera's point of view.

getV

public Vector3D getV()
Calculate the local "v" vector for the camera, pointing up from the camera's point of view, perpendicular to the line-of-sight.

Returns:
unit vector pointing up from the camera's point of view.

getN

public Vector3D getN()
Calculate the local "n" vector for the camera, pointing from the camera to the VRP, in the direction of the line-of-sight.

Returns:
unit vector pointing from the COP to the VRP

distance

public float distance()
Get the distance from the COP to the VRP.

Returns:
the distance from the COP to the VRP

public void SetViewVolume(float near,
                          float far,
                          float angle)
Set values for the near and far clipping planes and the view angle

Parameters:
near - the distance to the near clipping plane
far - the distance to the far clipping plane
angle - the angle (in degrees) subtended by the view volume in the y direction

getNear

public float getNear()
Get the distance to the near clipping plane

Returns:
distance to near clipping plane

getFar

public float getFar()
Get the distance to the far clipping plane

Returns:
distance to the far clipping plane

getViewAngle

public float getViewAngle()
Get the nominal view angle, in degrees

Returns:
the nominal view angle, subtended by the near clipping plane

MakeViewMatrix

public void MakeViewMatrix(net.java.games.jogl.GLDrawable drawable)
Call gluLookAt to set up the initial ModelView matrix, RT, based on the previously specified COP, VRP and VUV vectors. This method is not typically called directly by application programs. NOTE: It is assumed that the matrix mode is GL_MODELVIEW, and that the matrix stack has been reset at the time that this method is called.

Parameters:
drawable - The GLDrawable for the canvas.

MakeProjectionMatrix

public abstract void MakeProjectionMatrix(net.java.games.jogl.GLDrawable drawable,
                                          int width,
                                          int height)
Set up the projection matrix, based on the specified window dimensions and the current view angle and clipping planes. Concrete subclasses will implement this in different ways, depending on the type of projection needed. This method is not typically called directly by application programs. NOTE: It is assumed that the matrix mode is GL_PROJECTION.

Parameters:
drawable - The GLDrawable for this canvas.
width - The width of the window in pixels
height - The height of the window in pixels

getLineOfSight

public abstract Ray getLineOfSight(int x,
                                   int y,
                                   int width,
                                   int height)
Get a Ray in world coordinates corresponding to the line of sight through the specified pixel on a window with the specified dimensions.

Parameters:
x - pixel x coordinate
y - pixel y coordinate
width - the width of the current window in pixels
height - the width of the current window in pixels
Returns:
A Ray, starting at a point on the front clipping plane, along the line of sight through pixel ( x, y ) on the window.
